title: Ticket #1965: condor_master should be able to have its own PID namespace
description: When available, the master should spawn its own PID namepsace. This will help the performance of the procd (far less entries in /proc) and protect Condor from accidentally sending signals to non-Condor processes (a nice layer of security).
remarks:
2011-Mar-18 17:59:56 by bbockelm:
Ah - there's an oversight here: 

[root@brian-test ~]# cat /var/run/condor/condor_master.pid
1

If the condor_master writes its own PID file, it writes it as "1"; the RHEL daemon scripts sure don't like this.
attachments:
• condor_pid_namespaces_master_v1.patch 7701 bytes added by bbockelm on 2011-Mar-12 02:29:14 UTC.
    Attached patch implements a PID namespace for condor_master if the "-n" flag is given. Notes:
    • I had to duplicate some code - would be nice if someone could see a way around this.
    • Should this be the default? One thing I noticed was that the PIDs written to the log are not what the admin might expect...
    • Previously, Condor refuses to send signals to a PID less than 3; this has been removed.

  • condor_pid_namespaces_master_v2.patch 10379 bytes added by bbockelm on 2011-Mar-19 16:26:49 UTC.
    Second version of the patch. Notes:
    • This remains off by default. I'm still worried about a sysadmin getting "surprised" and not realizing the PIDs in the logfiles don't match the "global" PID.
    • I noticed that using the "-n" flag conflicts with "-n <instance>" command to the condor_master. Rather than change it and run afoul of another daemon's flags, I'd like a guru to suggest something.
    • On my test box, I found the combination of CLONE_VFORK, CLONE_NEWPID, and using PTRACE on the process caused CLONE_VFORK to not function. To safeguard against this, I use the same pipe/FD_CLOEXEC as in #1959; the two are complementary.
    • Dropping the pidfile is handled by daemon-core pre-fork instead of post-fork. Post-fork, the daemon thinks it is PID 1, making the pidfile less-than-useful. Note: because of this, the new daemon doesn't know to delete the file post-exec and leaves a turd. Suggestions?
